dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, antibiotics, right? I mean, probably one of humanity's most incredible achievements ever. They've saved, like, billions of lives.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, antibiotics, right? I mean, probably one of humanity's most incredible achievements ever. They've saved, like, billions of lives.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The development of antimicrobial medications is undoubtedly one of humankinds most incredible achievements, saving billions of lives in the roughly 100 years since they were first discovered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's pretty wild to think they've essentially doubled our life expectancy. But, uh, here's the kicker: antimicrobial resistance, or AMR.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's pretty wild to think they've essentially doubled our life expectancy. But, uh, here's the kicker: antimicrobial resistance, or A M R.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This single discovery has nearly doubled peoples life expectancy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty alarming how fast that popped up. Less than 20 years after penicillin was discovered, resistance was already detected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty alarming how fast that popped up. Less than twenty years after penicillin was discovered, resistance was already detected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet less than 20 years after penicillin was discovered, antimicrobial resistance (AMR) was first detected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And now it's, like, a huge public health threat. We're talking an estimated 1.3 million deaths annually now, directly because of AMR.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now it's, like, a huge public health threat. We're talking an estimated one point three million deaths annually now, directly because of A M R.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has compared antimicrobial resistance (AMR) to climate change in terms of its critical impact on global health. He highlighted the devastating toll of AMR, which currently claims 1.3 million lives annually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is why the UN General Assembly recently called it one of the world's most urgent health threats. It's serious stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is why the U N General Assembly recently called it one of the world's most urgent health threats. It's serious stuff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Indicating the seriousness of the AMR threat, the United Nations General Assembly recently recognized it as one of the worlds most urgent health threats and demanded immediate action to safeguard the ability to treat diseases and enhance food security.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Super serious. And that's why Saudi Arabia is currently hosting this big conference in Jeddah, right? Focusing on the WHO's "One Health" program.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Super serious. And that's why Saudi Arabia is currently hosting this big conference in Jeddah, right? Focusing on the W H O's One Health program.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Thats why the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is announcing a series of initiatives that support the World Health Organizations (WHOs) One Health program during the Fourth High-Level Global Ministerial Conference on AMR, which it is currently hosting in Jeddah.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. What sets "One Health" apart is its integrated approach. It's not just about human health, but also animals, agriculture, and the environment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. What sets One Health apart is its integrated approach. It's not just about human health, but also animals, agriculture, and the environment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What sets One Health apart from previous AMR resistance efforts is its integrated approach to the crisis. It is designed to drive actions in human health, animal health, agriculture and the environment to ensure that lifesaving antimicrobials continue to be available, while protecting against deadly resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes total sense, because it's all connected. And this conference, um, has the largest number of participating countries ever. That's a good sign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes total sense, because it's all connected. And this conference, um, has the largest number of participating countries ever. That's a good sign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 2024 AMR conference features the largest number of participating countries in the history of this bi-annual meeting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. They're all committing to things like better infection control and getting national action plans fully implemented.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. They're all committing to things like better infection control and getting national action plans fully implemented.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As a group, attending countries are demonstrating their commitment to: Doing a better job of preventing and controlling infections Fully implementing national AMR action plans

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and ensuring equitable access to antibiotics, too. Plus, they've got this new Jeddah Declaration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and ensuring equitable access to antibiotics, too. Plus, they've got this new Jeddah Declaration.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taking steps to provide equitable access to antibiotics, and... Specifically at this meeting, the agreed Jeddah Declaration titled, From Declaration to Implementation translates each countrys commitments into actions

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! It's got some interesting initiatives, like a global scientific panel to fight AMR, a "Biotech Bridge" for research, and even a learning hub for community awareness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! It's got some interesting initiatives, like a global scientific panel to fight A M R, a Biotech Bridge for research, and even a learning hub for community awareness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The establishment of a global scientific panel to study and fight AMR The creation of a Biotech Bridge that supports AMR-related research, development and innovation, and The development of a learning hub to boost community awareness of antimicrobial resistance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You know, what really struck me is WHO Director-General Tedros comparing AMR to climate change in terms of its global impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, what really struck me is W H O Director-General Tedros comparing A M R to climate change in terms of its global impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: World Health Organization Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has compared antimicrobial resistance (AMR) to climate change in terms of its critical impact on global health.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, I saw that! He also highlighted that ambition to reduce deaths from bacterial AMR by 10% by 2030. That's a huge target.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I saw that! He also highlighted that ambition to reduce deaths from bacterial A M R by ten percent by twenty thirty. That's a huge target.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The UN General Assembly's Political Declaration on AMR has set ambitious targets, including a 10% reduction in deaths from bacterial AMR by 2030, marking a significant step in the global fight against this growing threat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And he even mentioned that reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30% could boost global GDP by, like, $14 billion by 2050.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And he even mentioned that reducing antimicrobial use in animals by thirty percent could boost global G D P by, like, fourteen billion dollars by twenty fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Notably, he pointed out that reducing antimicrobial use in animals by 30% could potentially increase global GDP by US$14 billion by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa. That's a pretty compelling economic incentive right there. So, really highlights the need for international collaboration.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa. That's a pretty compelling economic incentive right there. So, really highlights the need for international collaboration.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And Dr. Hanan Balkhy from the WHO really praised Saudi Arabia's leadership in hosting this. They're, uh, truly stepping up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And Doctor Hanan Balkhy from the W H O really praised Saudi Arabia's leadership in hosting this. They're, uh, truly stepping up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Hanan Balkhy, WHO Regional Director for the Eastern Mediterranean, praised Saudi Arabias role as host of the Fourth AMR Ministerial Conference, and for its leadership initiatives. She said: The Kingdom is stepping up on the world stage to take on antimicrobial resistance, one of the most important and urgent global public health threats.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's all about building on current partnerships and forging new alliances to tackle this challenge head-on. We really can't afford to lose this fight.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's all about building on current partnerships and forging new alliances to tackle this challenge head-on. We really can't afford to lose this fight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We must build on current partnerships and forge new alliances to secure the health, safety, environment and economic development the world needs.
